title: Greatest Albums
text:
This data set from TidyTuesday originates from a Google Sheet compiled by Chris Eckert. It compares Rolling Stone’s “500 Greatest Albums of All Time” lists from 2003, 2012, and 2020 and includes information on each album’s name, genre, release year, 2003/2012/2020 rank, the artist’s name, birth year, gender, and more. This analysis looks at the trend in the production of the “greatest” albums over time. Which years were the most fruitful? Are artists getting worse at producing incredible albums?


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2024, week = 19)

rolling_stone <- tuesdata$rolling_stone

rolling_stone_df <- rolling_stone %>% 
  group_by(release_year) %>% 
  summarize(num_per_year = n_distinct(album))

ggplot(rolling_stone_df, aes(x = release_year, y = num_per_year)) +
  geom_point(color = "cadetblue") +
  geom_line(color = "cadetblue") +
  labs(
    title = "Rolling Stone's Greatest Albums of All Time",
    x = "Release Year",
    y = "Number of Albums Included in Top 500 Ranking",
  ) 









Source:
Rolling Stone Album Rankings: Tidy Tuesday Data from 2024-05-07
Dalla Riva, C., & Daniels, M. (n.d.). WHAT MAKES AN ALBUM THE GREATEST OF ALL TIME? The Pudding. https://pudding.cool/2024/03/greatest-music/.

title: Emma’s Site
text: Hi there! This is my first Quarto website, on which you can find two data visualizations I did. Both of them have to do with music, check out my About page to find out more :)

title: Musicians in the US
text:
This data is from TidyTuesday and is sourced from the National Endowment for the Arts. It gives state-level estimates for the total number of artists and for each individual type of artist in the workforce, covering 2015-2019. This analysis examines the total number of workers in the music industry specifically (musicians, music directors, and composers) and compares the totals across races.


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2022-09-27')
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2022, week = 39)

artists <- tuesdata$artists

artists2 <- artists %>%
  mutate(Music_Industry = str_detect(type, "Music")) %>%
  filter(Music_Industry == TRUE) %>%
  group_by(race) %>%
  summarize(total_musicians = sum(artists_n, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  mutate(race = fct_reorder(race, total_musicians, .desc = TRUE))


ggplot(artists2, aes(x = race, y = total_musicians)) +
  geom_col(fill = "lightblue") +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Music Industry Professionals Across Races in the US",
    x = "Race",
    y = "Number working as Musicians, Music Directors, or Composers",
  )









Source:
Artists in the USA: Tidy Tuesday Data from 2022-09-27
Artists in the Workforce: National and State Estimates for 2015-2019. (July 2022). National Endowment for the Arts. https://www.arts.gov/impact/research/arts-data-profile-series/adp-31.

title: About
text:
Hi! My name is Emma. For the sake of anonymity, I’ll leave out my last name.
The data visualizations you can find on the website both focus on music… I love music!
My favourite albums right now include the following:

“the record” by boygenius
“punisher” by phoebe bridgers
“home video” by lucy dacus 
“take the sadness out of saturday night” by bleachers

title: Text Analysis
text:
This data set contains 20,000 letters written in to Dear Abby, and was used in The Pudding essay “30 Years of American Anxieties: What 20,000 letters to an advice columnist tell us about what—and who—concerns us most.” The data contains letters published from 1985 to 2017.


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

dearabby <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/the-pudding/data/master/dearabby/raw_da_qs.csv")

dearabby1 <- dearabby %>% 
  mutate(title = str_to_lower(title)) %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(
    mom = sum(str_count(title, "mom*."), na.rm = TRUE), 
    dad = sum(str_count(title, "dad*."), na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(dearabby1, aes(year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = mom, color = "Mom")) +
  geom_line(aes(y = dad, color = "Dad")) +
  labs(
    title = "Mention of Mom and Dad in 'Dear Abby' Column Titles Over Time",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Frequency",
  )










This data visualization illustrates the frequency of use of “mom” and “dad” in the Dear Abby letters between 1985 and 2017. The plot demonstrates that both words have been employed more frequently over the course of the 30 years, despite the fact that the number of letters published per year remained constant (approximately one letter per day). Notably, the mention of “mom” and “dad” vary with one another, though “mom” reliably appears more often. The plot might suggest that writers have become more concerned with issues relating to/involving their parents in over the course of the past thirty years.


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

dearabby2 <- dearabby %>%
  mutate(self_verbs = str_extract_all(question_only, "(?<=i )\\w+")) %>% 
  unnest(self_verbs) %>%
  group_by(self_verbs) %>%
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(self_verbs, "(want$|wish$|hope$|pray$|expect$|beg$|require$)")) %>%
  arrange(count)

ggplot(dearabby2, aes(x = self_verbs, y = count)) +
  geom_col(fill = "lightblue") +
  labs(
    title = "Mention of Desire Verbs in 'Dear Abby' Questions",
    x = "Frequency of Use",
    y = "Expression of Desire",
  )









This data visualization seeks to model the use of verbs expressing personal desire. The top six verbs expressing desire (begging, expecting, hoping, praying, wanting, and wishing) were selected, and the frequency of their occurrence was compared. The only instances in which these occurrences were counted was in direct reference to the self (“I …”). This suggests that a far greater proportion of expressed their desires in terms of wanting something compared to hoping or praying for something.


Show the code
dearabby3 <- dearabby %>% 
  mutate(wants = str_detect(question_only, "\\bi want\\b")) %>% 
  filter(wants == TRUE) %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(want_count = sum(wants))

ggplot(dearabby3, aes(x = year, y = want_count)) +
  geom_point(color = "deepskyblue3") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "gray") +
  labs(
    title = "Mention of 'Wanting' in 'Dear Abby' Questions Over Time",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Expression of Wants",
  )









This data visualization further investigates the use of the phrase “I want”, which was found to be the most common expression of desire in the previous plot. The present analysis compares the frequency of the occurrence of this phrase over the course of the thirty years. The plot suggests that there is a weak positive correlation between time and expression of “wanting”.
Source:
Dear Abby: The Pudding on GitHub (2018).
Blinderman, I., Ralph, C., & Samora, R. (2018, November). 30 years of American anxieties. The Pudding. https://pudding.cool/2018/11/dearabby/.
